segment.source: Upgrade Surface devices to Windows 10 with Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (Surface)
segment.target: Upgrade Surface devices to Windows 10 with Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (Surface)

segment.source: Find out how to perform a Windows 10 upgrade deployment to your Surface devices.
segment.target: Find out how to perform a Windows 10 upgrade deployment to your Surface devices.

segment.source: windows 10 surface, upgrade, customize, mdt
segment.target: windows 10 surface, upgrade, customize, mdt

segment.source: Upgrade Surface devices to Windows 10 with Microsoft Deployment Toolkit
segment.target: Upgrade Surface devices to Windows 10 with Microsoft Deployment Toolkit

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Surface Pro 3
segment.target: Surface Pro 3

segment.source: Surface 3
segment.target: Surface 3

segment.source: Surface Pro 2
segment.target: Surface Pro 2

segment.source: Surface Pro
segment.target: Surface Pro

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: In addition to the traditional deployment method of reimaging devices, administrators that want to upgrade Surface devices that are running Windows 8.1 or Windows 10 have the option of deploying upgrades.
segment.target: In addition to the traditional deployment method of reimaging devices, administrators that want to upgrade Surface devices that are running Windows 8.1 or Windows 10 have the option of deploying upgrades.

segment.source: By performing an upgrade deployment, Windows 10 can be applied to devices without removing users, apps, or configuration.
segment.target: By performing an upgrade deployment, Windows 10 can be applied to devices without removing users, apps, or configuration.

segment.source: The users of the deployed devices can simply continue using the devices with the same apps and settings that they used prior to the upgrade.
segment.target: The users of the deployed devices can simply continue using the devices with the same apps and settings that they used prior to the upgrade.

segment.source: The process described in this article shows how to perform a Windows 10 upgrade deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: The process described in this article shows how to perform a Windows 10 upgrade deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: If you are not already familiar with the deployment of Windows or the Microsoft deployment tools and technologies, you should read Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT and familiarize yourself with the traditional deployment method before you proceed.
segment.target: If you are not already familiar with the deployment of Windows or the Microsoft deployment tools and technologies, you should read Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT and familiarize yourself with the traditional deployment method before you proceed.

segment.source: The upgrade concept
segment.target: The upgrade concept

segment.source: When you use the factory installation media to install Windows on a device, you are presented with two options or installation paths to install Windows on that device.
segment.target: When you use the factory installation media to install Windows on a device, you are presented with two options or installation paths to install Windows on that device.

segment.source: The first of these installation paths – clean installation – allows you to apply a factory image of Windows to that device, including all default settings.
segment.target: The first of these installation paths – clean installation – allows you to apply a factory image of Windows to that device, including all default settings.

segment.source: The second of these installation paths – upgrade – allows you to apply Windows to the device but retains the device’s users, apps, and settings.
segment.target: The second of these installation paths – upgrade – allows you to apply Windows to the device but retains the device’s users, apps, and settings.

segment.source: When you perform a Windows deployment using traditional deployment methods, you follow an installation path that is very similar to a clean installation.
segment.target: When you perform a Windows deployment using traditional deployment methods, you follow an installation path that is very similar to a clean installation.

segment.source: The primary difference between the clean installation and the traditional deployment method of reimaging is that with reimaging, you can apply an image that includes customizations.
segment.target: The primary difference between the clean installation and the traditional deployment method of reimaging is that with reimaging, you can apply an image that includes customizations.

segment.source: Microsoft deployment technologies, such as the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT), expand the capabilities of the reimaging process by modifying the image during deployment.
segment.target: Microsoft deployment technologies, such as the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT), expand the capabilities of the reimaging process by modifying the image during deployment.

segment.source: For example, MDT is able to inject drivers for a specific hardware configuration during deployment, and with pre and post imaging scripts to perform a number of tasks, such as the installation of applications.
segment.target: For example, MDT is able to inject drivers for a specific hardware configuration during deployment, and with pre and post imaging scripts to perform a number of tasks, such as the installation of applications.

segment.source: For versions of Windows prior to Windows 10, if you wanted to install a new version of Windows on your devices and preserve the configuration of those systems, you had to perform additional steps during your deployment.
segment.target: For versions of Windows prior to Windows 10, if you wanted to install a new version of Windows on your devices and preserve the configuration of those systems, you had to perform additional steps during your deployment.

segment.source: For example, if you wanted to keep the data of users on the device, you had to back up user data with the User State Migration Tool (USMT) prior to the deployment and restore that data after the deployment had completed.
segment.target: For example, if you wanted to keep the data of users on the device, you had to back up user data with the User State Migration Tool (USMT) prior to the deployment and restore that data after the deployment had completed.

segment.source: Introduced with Windows 10 and MDT 2013 Update 1, you can use the upgrade installation path directly with Microsoft deployment technologies such as the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT).
segment.target: Introduced with Windows 10 and MDT 2013 Update 1, you can use the upgrade installation path directly with Microsoft deployment technologies such as the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT).

segment.source: With an upgrade deployment you can use the same deployment technologies and process, but you can preserve users settings, and applications of the existing environment on the device.
segment.target: With an upgrade deployment you can use the same deployment technologies and process, but you can preserve users settings, and applications of the existing environment on the device.

segment.source: Deployment tools and resources
segment.target: Deployment tools and resources

segment.source: Performing an upgrade deployment of Windows 10 requires the same tools and resources that are required for a traditional reimaging deployment.
segment.target: Performing an upgrade deployment of Windows 10 requires the same tools and resources that are required for a traditional reimaging deployment.

segment.source: You can read about the tools required, including detailed explanations and installation instructions, in Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT.
segment.target: You can read about the tools required, including detailed explanations and installation instructions, in Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT.

segment.source: To proceed with the upgrade deployment described in this article, you will need the following tools installed and configured:
segment.target: To proceed with the upgrade deployment described in this article, you will need the following tools installed and configured:

segment.source: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT)
segment.target: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT)

segment.source: Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), which includes:
segment.target: Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), which includes:

segment.source: Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM)
segment.target: Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM)

segment.source: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE)
segment.target: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE)

segment.source: Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM)
segment.target: Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM)

segment.source: You will also need to have available the following resources:
segment.target: You will also need to have available the following resources:

segment.source: Windows 10 installation files, such as the installation media downloaded from the Volume Licensing Service Center
segment.target: Windows 10 installation files, such as the installation media downloaded from the Volume Licensing Service Center

segment.source: Note:Installation media for use with MDT must contain a Windows image in Windows Imaging Format (.wim).
segment.target: Note:Installation media for use with MDT must contain a Windows image in Windows Imaging Format (.wim).

segment.source: Installation media produced by the Get Windows 10 page does not use a .wim file, instead using an Electronic Software Download (.esd) file, which is not compatible with MDT.
segment.target: Installation media produced by the Get Windows 10 page does not use a .wim file, instead using an Electronic Software Download (.esd) file, which is not compatible with MDT.

segment.source: Surface firmware and drivers for Windows 10
segment.target: Surface firmware and drivers for Windows 10

segment.source: Application installation files for any applications you want to install, such as the Surface app
segment.target: Application installation files for any applications you want to install, such as the Surface app

segment.source: Prepare the upgrade deployment
segment.target: Prepare the upgrade deployment

segment.source: Before you begin the process described in this section, you need to have installed and configured the deployment tools outlined in the previous Deployment tools and resources section.
segment.target: Before you begin the process described in this section, you need to have installed and configured the deployment tools outlined in the previous Deployment tools and resources section.

segment.source: For instructions on how to install and configure the deployment tools, see the Install the deployment tools section in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article.
segment.target: For instructions on how to install and configure the deployment tools, see the Install the deployment tools section in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article.

segment.source: You will also have needed to create a deployment share with MDT, described in the section Create a Deployment Share in the aforementioned article.
segment.target: You will also have needed to create a deployment share with MDT, described in the section Create a Deployment Share in the aforementioned article.

segment.source: Import Windows 10 installation files
segment.target: Import Windows 10 installation files

segment.source: Windows 10 installation files only need to be imported if you have not already done so in the deployment share.
segment.target: Windows 10 installation files only need to be imported if you have not already done so in the deployment share.

segment.source: To import Windows 10 installation files, follow the steps described in the Import Windows installation files section in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article.
segment.target: To import Windows 10 installation files, follow the steps described in the Import Windows installation files section in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article.

segment.source: Import Surface drivers
segment.target: Import Surface drivers

segment.source: In the import process example shown in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article, drivers for Surface Pro 4 were imported for Windows 10.
segment.target: In the import process example shown in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article, drivers for Surface Pro 4 were imported for Windows 10.

segment.source: To perform an upgrade deployment of Windows 10 to Surface Pro 3, drivers for Surface Pro 3 must also be imported.
segment.target: To perform an upgrade deployment of Windows 10 to Surface Pro 3, drivers for Surface Pro 3 must also be imported.

segment.source: To import the Surface drivers for Surface Pro 3, follow these steps:
segment.target: To import the Surface drivers for Surface Pro 3, follow these steps:

segment.source: Download the Surface Pro 3 firmware and driver pack for Windows 10 archive file (.zip), SurfacePro3_Win10_xxxxxx.zip, from the Surface Pro 3 download page in the Microsoft Download Center.
segment.target: Download the Surface Pro 3 firmware and driver pack for Windows 10 archive file (.zip), SurfacePro3_Win10_xxxxxx.zip, from the Surface Pro 3 download page in the Microsoft Download Center.

segment.source: Extract the contents of the Surface Pro 3 firmware and driver pack archive file to a temporary folder.
segment.target: Extract the contents of the Surface Pro 3 firmware and driver pack archive file to a temporary folder.

segment.source: Keep the driver files separate from other drivers or files.
segment.target: Keep the driver files separate from other drivers or files.

segment.source: Open the Deployment Workbench and expand the Deployment Shares node and your deployment share.
segment.target: Open the Deployment Workbench and expand the Deployment Shares node and your deployment share.

segment.source: If you have not already created a folder structure by operating system version, you should do so next.
segment.target: If you have not already created a folder structure by operating system version, you should do so next.

segment.source: Under the Windows 10 x64 folder, create a new folder for Surface Pro 3 drivers named Surface Pro 3.
segment.target: Under the Windows 10 x64 folder, create a new folder for Surface Pro 3 drivers named Surface Pro 3.

segment.source: Your Out-of-Box Drivers folder should resemble the following structure:
segment.target: Your Out-of-Box Drivers folder should resemble the following structure:

segment.source: WinPE x86
segment.target: WinPE x86

segment.source: WinPE x64
segment.target: WinPE x64

segment.source: Windows 10 x64
segment.target: Windows 10 x64

segment.source: Microsoft Corporation
segment.target: Microsoft Corporation

segment.source: Surface Pro 4
segment.target: Surface Pro 4

segment.source: Surface Pro 3
segment.target: Surface Pro 3

segment.source: Right-click the Surface Pro 3 folder, and then click Import Drivers to start the Import Drivers Wizard, as shown in Figure 1.
segment.target: Right-click the Surface Pro 3 folder, and then click Import Drivers to start the Import Drivers Wizard, as shown in Figure 1.

segment.source: Import Surface Pro 3 drivers for Windows 10
segment.target: Import Surface Pro 3 drivers for Windows 10

segment.source: Figure 1.
segment.target: Figure 1.

segment.source: Import Surface Pro 3 drivers for Windows 10
segment.target: Import Surface Pro 3 drivers for Windows 10

segment.source: The Import Driver Wizard displays a series of steps, as follows:
segment.target: The Import Driver Wizard displays a series of steps, as follows:

segment.source: Specify Directory – Click Browse and navigate to the folder where you extracted the Surface Pro 3 firmware and drivers in Step 1.
segment.target: Specify Directory – Click Browse and navigate to the folder where you extracted the Surface Pro 3 firmware and drivers in Step 1.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin the import process.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin the import process.

segment.source: Progress – While the drivers are imported, a progress bar is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Progress – While the drivers are imported, a progress bar is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the import process completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the import process completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete Import Drivers Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete Import Drivers Wizard.

segment.source: Select the Surface Pro 3 folder and verify that the folder now contains the drivers that were imported, as shown in Figure 2.
segment.target: Select the Surface Pro 3 folder and verify that the folder now contains the drivers that were imported, as shown in Figure 2.

segment.source: Drivers for Surface Pro 3 imported and organized in the MDT deployment share
segment.target: Drivers for Surface Pro 3 imported and organized in the MDT deployment share

segment.source: Figure 2.
segment.target: Figure 2.

segment.source: Drivers for Surface Pro 3 imported and organized in the MDT deployment share
segment.target: Drivers for Surface Pro 3 imported and organized in the MDT deployment share

segment.source: Import applications
segment.target: Import applications

segment.source: Installation of applications in an upgrade deployment is not always necessary because the applications from the previous environment will remain on the device.
segment.target: Installation of applications in an upgrade deployment is not always necessary because the applications from the previous environment will remain on the device.

segment.source: (For example, in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article, the deployment includes Office 365 which is not required in an upgrade deployment where the user is already using Office 365 on the device.)
segment.target: (For example, in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article, the deployment includes Office 365 which is not required in an upgrade deployment where the user is already using Office 365 on the device.)

segment.source: There are still some circumstances where you will want to deploy an application, even during an upgrade deployment.
segment.target: There are still some circumstances where you will want to deploy an application, even during an upgrade deployment.

segment.source: For example, you may have Surface Pro 3 devices on which you would like to add the Surface app.
segment.target: For example, you may have Surface Pro 3 devices on which you would like to add the Surface app.

segment.source: To deploy the Surface app in an upgrade scenario use the same process as you would for a traditional deployment.
segment.target: To deploy the Surface app in an upgrade scenario use the same process as you would for a traditional deployment.

segment.source: See the Deploy Surface app with Windows Store for Business article for instructions on how to add the Surface app to an MDT task sequence.
segment.target: See the Deploy Surface app with Windows Store for Business article for instructions on how to add the Surface app to an MDT task sequence.

segment.source: Create the upgrade task sequence
segment.target: Create the upgrade task sequence

segment.source: After you have all of the resources in place to perform the deployment (including the installation files, Surface drivers, and application files), the next step is to create the upgrade task sequence.
segment.target: After you have all of the resources in place to perform the deployment (including the installation files, Surface drivers, and application files), the next step is to create the upgrade task sequence.

segment.source: This task sequence is a series of steps that will be performed on the device being upgraded that applies the new Windows environment, compatible drivers, and any applications you have specified.
segment.target: This task sequence is a series of steps that will be performed on the device being upgraded that applies the new Windows environment, compatible drivers, and any applications you have specified.

segment.source: Create the upgrade task sequence with the following process:
segment.target: Create the upgrade task sequence with the following process:

segment.source: In the Deployment Workbench under your Deployment Share, right-click the Task Sequences folder, and then click New Task Sequence to start the New Task Sequence Wizard.
segment.target: In the Deployment Workbench under your Deployment Share, right-click the Task Sequences folder, and then click New Task Sequence to start the New Task Sequence Wizard.

segment.source: Use these steps to create the deployment task sequence with the New Task Sequence Wizard:
segment.target: Use these steps to create the deployment task sequence with the New Task Sequence Wizard:

segment.source: General Settings – Enter an identifier for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence ID field, a name for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence Name field, and any comments for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence Comments field, and then click Next.
segment.target: General Settings – Enter an identifier for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence ID field, a name for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence Name field, and any comments for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence Comments field, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note:The Task Sequence ID field cannot contain spaces and can be a maximum of 16 characters.
segment.target: Note:The Task Sequence ID field cannot contain spaces and can be a maximum of 16 characters.

segment.source: Select Template – Select Standard Client Upgrade Task Sequence from the drop-down menu, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select Template – Select Standard Client Upgrade Task Sequence from the drop-down menu, and then click Next.

segment.source: Select OS – Navigate to and select the Windows image that you imported, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select OS – Navigate to and select the Windows image that you imported, and then click Next.

segment.source: Specify Product Key – Select the product key entry that fits your organization’s licensing system.
segment.target: Specify Product Key – Select the product key entry that fits your organization’s licensing system.

segment.source: The Do Not Specify a Product Key at This Time option can be used for systems that will be activated via Key Management Services (KMS) or Active Directory Based Activation (ADBA).
segment.target: The Do Not Specify a Product Key at This Time option can be used for systems that will be activated via Key Management Services (KMS) or Active Directory Based Activation (ADBA).

segment.source: A product key can be specified specifically if your organization uses Multiple Activation Keys (MAK).
segment.target: A product key can be specified specifically if your organization uses Multiple Activation Keys (MAK).

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: OS Settings – Enter a name and organization for registration of Windows, and a home page URL for users when they browse the Internet in the Full Name, Organization, and Internet Explorer Home Page fields, and then click Next.
segment.target: OS Settings – Enter a name and organization for registration of Windows, and a home page URL for users when they browse the Internet in the Full Name, Organization, and Internet Explorer Home Page fields, and then click Next.

segment.source: Admin Password – Select Use the Specified Local Administrator Password and enter a password in the provided fields, and then click Next.
segment.target: Admin Password – Select Use the Specified Local Administrator Password and enter a password in the provided fields, and then click Next.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin creation of the task sequence.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin creation of the task sequence.

segment.source: Progress – While the task sequence is being created, a progress bar is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Progress – While the task sequence is being created, a progress bar is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the task sequence creation completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the task sequence creation completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete New Task Sequence Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete New Task Sequence Wizard.

segment.source: After the task sequence is created, you can modify some additional settings to provide additional automation of the task sequence and require less interaction during deployment.
segment.target: After the task sequence is created, you can modify some additional settings to provide additional automation of the task sequence and require less interaction during deployment.

segment.source: Follow these steps to modify the task sequence:
segment.target: Follow these steps to modify the task sequence:

segment.source: Select the Task Sequences folder, right-click the new task sequence you created, and then click Properties.
segment.target: Select the Task Sequences folder, right-click the new task sequence you created, and then click Properties.

segment.source: Select the Task Sequence tab to view the steps that are included in the new task sequence.
segment.target: Select the Task Sequence tab to view the steps that are included in the new task sequence.

segment.source: Select the Windows Update (Pre-Application Installation) step, located under the State Restore folder.
segment.target: Select the Windows Update (Pre-Application Installation) step, located under the State Restore folder.

segment.source: Click the Options tab, and then clear the Disable This Step check box.
segment.target: Click the Options tab, and then clear the Disable This Step check box.

segment.source: Repeat Step 3 and Step 4 for the Windows Update (Post-Application Installation) step.
segment.target: Repeat Step 3 and Step 4 for the Windows Update (Post-Application Installation) step.

segment.source: Between the two Windows Update steps is an Install Applications step.
segment.target: Between the two Windows Update steps is an Install Applications step.

segment.source: Select that step and then click Add.
segment.target: Select that step and then click Add.

segment.source: Hover the mouse over General under the Add menu, and then choose Install Application.
segment.target: Hover the mouse over General under the Add menu, and then choose Install Application.

segment.source: This will add a new step after the selected step for the installation of a specific application as shown in Figure 3.
segment.target: This will add a new step after the selected step for the installation of a specific application as shown in Figure 3.

segment.source: A new Install Application step in the deployment task sequence
segment.target: A new Install Application step in the deployment task sequence

segment.source: Figure 3.
segment.target: Figure 3.

segment.source: A new Install Application step in the deployment task sequence
segment.target: A new Install Application step in the deployment task sequence

segment.source: On the Properties tab of the new Install Application step, enter Install Surface App in the Name field.
segment.target: On the Properties tab of the new Install Application step, enter Install Surface App in the Name field.

segment.source: Select Install a Single Application, and then click Browse to view available applications that have been imported into the deployment share.
segment.target: Select Install a Single Application, and then click Browse to view available applications that have been imported into the deployment share.

segment.source: Select Surface App from the list of applications, and then click OK.
segment.target: Select Surface App from the list of applications, and then click OK.

segment.source: Expand the Preinstall folder and select the Enable BitLocker (Offline) step.
segment.target: Expand the Preinstall folder and select the Enable BitLocker (Offline) step.

segment.source: Open the Add menu again and choose Set Task Sequence Variable from under the General menu.
segment.target: Open the Add menu again and choose Set Task Sequence Variable from under the General menu.

segment.source: On the Properties tab of the new Set Task Sequence Variable step (as shown in Figure 4) configure the following options:
segment.target: On the Properties tab of the new Set Task Sequence Variable step (as shown in Figure 4) configure the following options:

segment.source: Name – Set DriverGroup001
segment.target: Name – Set DriverGroup001

segment.source: Task Sequence Variable – DriverGroup001
segment.target: Task Sequence Variable – DriverGroup001

segment.source: Value – Windows 10 x64\%Make%\%Model%
segment.target: Value – Windows 10 x64\%Make%\%Model%

segment.source: Configure a new Set Task Sequence Variable step in the deployment task sequence
segment.target: Configure a new Set Task Sequence Variable step in the deployment task sequence

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: Configure a new Set Task Sequence Variable step in the deployment task sequence
segment.target: Configure a new Set Task Sequence Variable step in the deployment task sequence

segment.source: Select the Inject Drivers step, the next step in the task sequence.
segment.target: Select the Inject Drivers step, the next step in the task sequence.

segment.source: On the Properties tab of the Inject Drivers step (as shown in Figure 5) configure the following options:
segment.target: On the Properties tab of the Inject Drivers step (as shown in Figure 5) configure the following options:

segment.source: In the Choose a selection profile drop-down menu, select Nothing.
segment.target: In the Choose a selection profile drop-down menu, select Nothing.

segment.source: Click the Install all drivers from the selection profile button.
segment.target: Click the Install all drivers from the selection profile button.

segment.source: Configure the deployment task sequence to not install drivers
segment.target: Configure the deployment task sequence to not install drivers

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: Configure the deployment task sequence to not install drivers
segment.target: Configure the deployment task sequence to not install drivers

segment.source: Click OK to apply changes to the task sequence and close the task sequence properties window.
segment.target: Click OK to apply changes to the task sequence and close the task sequence properties window.

segment.source: Steps 11 through 15 are very important to the deployment of Surface devices.
segment.target: Steps 11 through 15 are very important to the deployment of Surface devices.

segment.source: These steps instruct the task sequence to install only drivers that are organized into the correct folder using the organization for drivers from the Import Surface drivers section.
segment.target: These steps instruct the task sequence to install only drivers that are organized into the correct folder using the organization for drivers from the Import Surface drivers section.

segment.source: Deployment share rules
segment.target: Deployment share rules

segment.source: To automate the upgrade process, the rules of the MDT deployment share need to be modified to suppress prompts for information from the user.
segment.target: To automate the upgrade process, the rules of the MDT deployment share need to be modified to suppress prompts for information from the user.

segment.source: Unlike a traditional deployment, Bootstrap.ini does not need to be modified because the deployment process is not started from boot media.
segment.target: Unlike a traditional deployment, Bootstrap.ini does not need to be modified because the deployment process is not started from boot media.

segment.source: Similarly, boot media does not need to be imported into WDS because it will not be booted over the network with PXE.
segment.target: Similarly, boot media does not need to be imported into WDS because it will not be booted over the network with PXE.

segment.source: To modify the deployment share rules and suppress the Windows Deployment Wizard prompts for information, copy and paste the following text into the text box on the Rules tab of your deployment share properties:
segment.target: To modify the deployment share rules and suppress the Windows Deployment Wizard prompts for information, copy and paste the following text into the text box on the Rules tab of your deployment share properties:

segment.source: For more information about the rules configured by this text, see the Configure deployment share rules section in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article.
segment.target: For more information about the rules configured by this text, see the Configure deployment share rules section in the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article.

segment.source: Update deployment share
segment.target: Update deployment share

segment.source: To update the deployment share, right-click the deployment share in the Deployment Workbench and click Update Deployment Share, then proceed through the Update Deployment Share Wizard.
segment.target: To update the deployment share, right-click the deployment share in the Deployment Workbench and click Update Deployment Share, then proceed through the Update Deployment Share Wizard.

segment.source: See the Update and import updated MDT boot media section of the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article for detailed steps.
segment.target: See the Update and import updated MDT boot media section of the Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with MDT article for detailed steps.

segment.source: Run the upgrade deployment
segment.target: Run the upgrade deployment

segment.source: Unlike a traditional deployment, the upgrade task sequence must be launched from within the Windows environment that will be upgraded.
segment.target: Unlike a traditional deployment, the upgrade task sequence must be launched from within the Windows environment that will be upgraded.

segment.source: This requires that a user on the device to be upgraded navigate to the deployment share over the network and launch a script, LiteTouch.vbs.
segment.target: This requires that a user on the device to be upgraded navigate to the deployment share over the network and launch a script, LiteTouch.vbs.

segment.source: This script is the same script that displays the Windows Deployment Wizard in Windows PE in a traditional deployment.
segment.target: This script is the same script that displays the Windows Deployment Wizard in Windows PE in a traditional deployment.

segment.source: In this scenario, Litetouch.vbs will run within Windows.
segment.target: In this scenario, Litetouch.vbs will run within Windows.

segment.source: To perform the upgrade task sequence and deploy the upgrade to Windows 10 follow these steps:
segment.target: To perform the upgrade task sequence and deploy the upgrade to Windows 10 follow these steps:

segment.source: Browse to the network location of your deployment share in File Explorer.
segment.target: Browse to the network location of your deployment share in File Explorer.

segment.source: Navigate to the Scripts folder, locate LiteTouch.vbs, and then double-click LiteTouch.vbs to start the Windows Deployment Wizard.
segment.target: Navigate to the Scripts folder, locate LiteTouch.vbs, and then double-click LiteTouch.vbs to start the Windows Deployment Wizard.

segment.source: Enter your credentials when prompted.
segment.target: Enter your credentials when prompted.

segment.source: The upgrade task sequence for Surface Pro 3 devices will automatically start when the model of the device is detected and determined to match the deployment share rules.
segment.target: The upgrade task sequence for Surface Pro 3 devices will automatically start when the model of the device is detected and determined to match the deployment share rules.

segment.source: The upgrade process will occur automatically and without user interaction.
segment.target: The upgrade process will occur automatically and without user interaction.

segment.source: The task sequence will automatically install the drivers for Surface Pro 3 and the Surface app, and will perform any outstanding Windows Updates.
segment.target: The task sequence will automatically install the drivers for Surface Pro 3 and the Surface app, and will perform any outstanding Windows Updates.

segment.source: When it completes, it will log out and be ready for the user to log on with the credentials they have always used for this device.
segment.target: When it completes, it will log out and be ready for the user to log on with the credentials they have always used for this device.
